net.sf.mmm.client.ui.api

Interface UiConfiguration

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractUiConfiguration, UiConfigurationBean, UiConfigurationDefault

    public interface UiConfiguration
    This is the interface for the configuration of the UI (user interface).
    ATTENTION:
    This is an extendable interface.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static String DEFAULT_THEME
      The default value for theme.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_THEME

        static final String DEFAULT_THEME
        The default value for theme.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getTheme

        String getTheme()
        This method gets the path for the current theme. This is attached to all relative image URLs. You can use this to switch to a different theme in order to get a different appearance of the UI. Typically you decide for a theme at build-time. However, this allows to switch themes at runtime.
        Returns:
        the URL path for the current theme.

      • getLabelLookup

        NlsMessageLookup getLabelLookup()
        This method gets the instance of NlsMessageLookup used to lookup labels automatically by property titles via UiDataBinding. So you can highly customize your labels for your custom defined properties and have full I18N/l10n support with little effort. For rapid development you can also ignore all this and just live with the property title that is used as fallback if lookup fails.
        For full support you create an interface e.g. NlsBundleMyLabelsRoot that extends from NlsBundleWithLookup. For further details look at NlsBundle. For each property title such as lastName you define an according method in your bundle (NlsBundleMyLabelsRoot):
         public interface NlsBundleMyLabelsRoot extends NlsBundleWithLookup {
    @NlsBundleMessage("Last name")
   NlsMessage lastName();
   ...
 }
        E.g. for German localization you define NlsBundleMyLabels_de.properties in the same package with this content: 
         lastName = Nachname
 ...
        Now we assume you have a business object like this: 
         public interface Partner {

   TypedProperty <String> PROPERTY_LAST_NAME = new TypedProperty <>("lastName", String.class);

 }
        you can use createAndBind(Partner.PROPERTY_LAST_NAME) to create an input field widget and the label will be set automatically to your localized label text ("Last Name", "Vorname", or whatever).
        Now if you refactor your code so the property lastName gets renamed to surename and you want to keep your NLS/I18N properties stable, you can change your declaration to 
         public interface Partner {

   TypedProperty <String> PROPERTY_LAST_NAME = new TypedProperty <>("surename", String.class, "lastName");

 }
        And maybe also rename it to PROPERTY_SURENAME.
        You could also use "Partner_surename" as property title if you want to have a different label for surename in a different business object e.g. Address. You only need to ensure that the property title matches the method name and therefore key in your NlsBundleWithLookup. You can also use "Partner.surename" with the following trick: 
            @NlsBundleKey("Partner.surename")
    @NlsBundleMessage("Last name")
   NlsMessage PartnerSurename();

        NOTE:
        It is recommended to specify the property type in your TypedProperty constant. However, this is technically not required and you may also omit it. This might cause a little performance overhead as the property type has to be reflected then. Also you need to be careful not to pick the wrong constructor for this purpose such as TypedProperty.TypedProperty(String, String).
        Returns:
        the NlsMessageLookup instance for automatic label creation. You should typically use NlsMessageLookupProxy in your custom implementation of this method.
        See Also:
        UiDataBinding
